idea: After uploading an image for the web or email, automatically create all common media query sizes and optimize them for low weight and high quality like Squarespace does. On Squarespace support site:
> Squarespace takes the guesswork out of formatting your images for display on the web. We create seven variations of each uploaded image, to ensure perfect display on any screen size.
<https://support.squarespace.com/hc/en-us/articles/206542517-Formatting-your-images-for-display-on-the-web>

They do this by default, but say you’re using an image as a background image (where HubSpot wouldn’t know the dimensions you want) or if you need to specify your own dimensions you can use this hubl function:
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/en/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-functions#resize-image-url>
HubSpot Drag n Drop template builder annoyances (this is a rant thread but would appreciate if these things were solved)

The style controls are infuriating (padding/ margin)

Padding actually uses actual css padding - which is a no-no in email templates because padding isn’t rendered properly in outlook, windows 10 mail, and IBM Notes

The Margin control is useless because it applies it to a TD element <https://spin.d.pr/VUGyA7+>

TD elements margin is ignored.

in addition margin in email needs to be done like this:
```
margin: 1px 2px 3px 4px;
Margin: 1px 2px 3px 4px;
```
note the upper and lower-case version of Margin. That’s because most versions of outlook use Word as it’s rendering engine. meaning it supports `Margin` but not `margin`

The class field on the drag n drop elements puts the class on the TD’s not the table elements themselves. making them a pain in the butt to work with because you have to use classes on outer elements and do selecters like `table.card-outer-wrapper>tbody>tr>td{}`

because of issues like this any time a client tells me they want it to be a drag n drop editor email template I feel like I’m spending hours just fighting the template editor instead of building the email
